reviewText:
Disclaimer I'll start off by saying that my review of this game is based off the 30+ hours (probably more) I spent playing Devilian during its Beta and Alpha stage. The last time I played it was around two weeks prior to official release. I played the game pretty much to completion with a max level Cannoneer on the Beta server. Although my experience with the max level content was limited, what was available was pretty much the same earlier dungeons just scaled up.

Basically (TL;DR), the game is alright, and its free so you might as well give it a bash.
If you're seeking any sort of challenge the leveling phase is completely lacking in it, the combat is interesting albeit very spammy, the quests are dreadfully repetitive, and the world art design is nice. As far as MMOs go, it's probably one of the best I've played in recent years, though please take that with the consideration that I'm someone who is pretty much burnt out on MMOs after years of WoW and a spurt of others, so I tend to avoid them. Though with that mindset taken into consideration, the fact that I was able to be interested and for the most part enjoy my 30plus hours with Devilian should be taken as a fairly strong endorsement.

So.. let's get started!

The Good:
As far as MMOs go, this is a prety good combat system. If you're familiar with Diablo 3, Neverwinter, DOTA2, LoL, etc.. it's a lot like that, just with more abilities available to use at any one time. Depends on the sort of movement style you choose to play with, I suppose. The game includes options for typical WASD style, or left or right click to move. I personally went with click to move and that worked fairly well. My only complaint here would be that it's very spammy. As in you need to click or hold a button or key to spam out the same ability a lot.
Some games hurt my hand after prolong periods of play, and towards the end of my time with this game, it got onto that list (my problem is nothing major, but it was definitely uncomfortable). If you have problems like carpal tunnel syndrome you might need to get creative with your control setup, particularly where you bind your spamming skills.
(World) Art style is good, imo. This is of course subjective but I personally liked the artstyle for the world in this game. The game is very clearly heavily inspired by the Diablo series, most notably Diablo 3. If you have played that game you will no doubt find many of the areas around the world and even some enemies to be quite familiar. And I don't view this as a negative, as I did like Diablo 3 and in general I think the influence it seems to have had on this game's art direction is a positive one.
My complaint on the art style would be that I'm not a great fan of the gender-locked classes, although I can understand it being done most likely on budget concerns. However adding gender options in the future is definitely a way this game could be improved upon. I'm especially not a big fan of my favorite class to play, the Cannoneer, being a Loli (little anime girl). The character in this particular game is not as offensive or perverted as they can get though, so it wasn't a deal breaker for me, but I'd still have preferred an alternative.
It's a good candidate if you're looking for some mindless entertainment when you're tired.
The Bad:
The game is far too easy for basically the entirity of the leveling phase, and the only real challenge comes when you reach max level and begin running Hell difficulty dungeons with the blues you were leveling with. To me this is bad pacing, plain and simple. A tutorial is something that should last maybe 10, 20, 30 minutes. Maybe an hour or two if your game is really complex. But let's be honest, this is an MMO that plays very much like Diablo 3 or a moba/dota-style game. The complexity found here is not exactly on the level of Chess. So for you to tell me that the entire leveling process up to max level is a 15 to 20+ hour tutorial or learning phase" can only come across as an insult. I know this is par for the course for MMOs to have stupidly easy leveling content

reviewText:
Pros

*FREE - Don't have to spend a dime to enjoy
*Lots of skills to choose from
*Dungeons with bosses
*Achievements
*Unlimited respec for FREE
*4 classes (5th being made) Each class has 3 specializations (specs)
*PvP/PvE - LOTS of questing (see con)
*Daily questing for gold/tokens
*Not pay to win
*Lots of gear sets throughout your adventure
*Looking For Group tool
*Lots of gameplay from level 1-52 +endgame grinding (see con)
*Enchanting/Socketing
*Paragon System
*Adding friends has benefits such as daily xp, mats and gold
*Joining a guild has benefits such as daily xp, mats, gold, convenience and saving you gold with discounts.
*Low system requirements (my 8 year old PC played this perfectly)

Cons

*Gender locked specific classes
*Need to spend real money one time ($5) to open up the Auction House - if you've spent money in a Trion game before this need not apply to you and you will already have a verified account.
*Limited bag space
*Not complete
*No open world PvP (PvP is instanced)
*Minor bugs (not game breaking)
*No wardrobe system
*End game grinding
*LOTS of questing

Devilian is a Massive Multiplayer Online Action Role Playing Game (MMOARPG) and I loved it.  Take a Diablo 3/Torchlight type of game and mix in games like World of Craft and this is what you get.

There are 4 classes in total at the moment.
1.  Evoker - female mage (range with magic)
2.  Cannoneer - female gunner (range with guns)
3.  Shadowhunter - male melee (melee/range hybrid)(looks like someone out of Castlevania)
4.  Berserker - male melee (wields two 1h swords)

Each class has 3 different specializations that you can put ability points into.  You gain 1 ability point per level once you reach level 10.  You can make a pure 1 spec build or dip points into all 3 specs and make a hybrid.  There's nothing holding you back if you'd like to try things out and have fun with this specialization tree.  Respecialization (respec) is completely free and you can do it as many times and as often as you like.

Max level as of this writing is lvl 52.  After about 60 hours I've did ALL the quests available, multiple PvP sessions and have completed the tier 1 PvE set.  There are a total of 3 tiers at the moment.  Tier 1 is the Falling Star set which is blue (rare) equipment.  The next set tier 2 is the Butchery set which is epic (purple) and the final set tier 3 is the Tragedy set and it too is epic (purple).  When reaching max level 52 the grind starts.  Grinding for tokens to complete tier 2 and/or 3 and get gems to socket your gear.

There is PvP in the game and it's set up like a MOBO (think DOTA).  You pick a lane, capture and hold it while killing off the enemy players.  At the moment it seems very range friendly and the melee classes just feel undesired.  You can either play as your human form and use the skills you've acquired or take on your specific Devilian form.

Devilian form is like your Super Saiyen and when you go Devilian you are stronger, faster and harder to kill.  Very fun aspect of the game.  You can either use this in PvP or in PvE.  In PvE you get devil orbs which will help fill your Devilian meter.  Once full you can morph into Devilian form and wreck havok!

There are over 20 dungeons and all are extremely fast paced.  Each dungeon shouldn't take you 10 mins to complete.  Once you hit max level you can queue up for Heroic versions of the dungeons you've did while leveling and once you feel comfortable with that difficulty you can advance to Hell difficulty.  Each difficulty whether it be Normal, Heroic or Hell has 3 tiers and are named +1, +2 or +3.  Each of these +1 are more difficult by means of monster health and how much damage they do to you, but the benefit is more loot!

The game is free to play and you can enjoy the whole game without paying a dime, but if you choose to support the game you can pay for extra bag space, more xp, more gold, different types of mounts (they give you one free) and cosmetics.  Nothing overpowering makes this a pay to win title and should be classified as a pay for convenience.  Other conveniences are an auto run feature that allows you to kick back and let your character run to either the quest giver or the objectives.  I found this nice.  You can sit back and take a drink or get your smoke on for a min.  There are fast travel nodes all over the world too.  So if you don't feel up to traversing the world to get to the other side of it you can use this, but with payment of in game gold.

The major town hub isn't overpopulated, but has a lot of people there doing quests, the auction house, warehouse (store more stuff outside your bag inventory), chat and enchanting gear.  There are still two major continents that have yet to be opened up and the level cap is supposed to increase by the 1st quarter of 2016.  There are still 3 more tiers of gear and Raids to be implemented as well.

There's also a Paragon system once you reach end game level cap.  Meaning, once you reach level 52 you can no longer gain any more levels, but instead the experience you gained can be dumped into another set of proficiencies like the Paragon sytem Diablo 3 has.  When dumping points into this system all your characters will share extended health, more gold per kill, more xp per kill, more damage toward bosses and so forth.  The system still needs some work and shouldn't be bound to all your characters, but at least all that precious xp is wasted!

Lastly, there's a tower to test your skills at and it opens up around level 25ish called the Abyssal Tower.  In this tower you climb up floors of non stop enemies and bosses until you reach the top floor at 100.  As you get better gear and respec your character to fine tune him you will ascend higher into the tower.  You will get XP for your Devilian form in doing this and making yourself even stronger.  You can only do this tower once a day so make sure you do it for it's totally worth it.  There's even a leaders board for this tower for some friendly competition.

As it stands Devilian was extremely great and I very much enjoyed my 60 hours of gameplay, but once I hit max level I've seemed to hit a brick wall.  Due to Devilian being content starved either you grind out endgame mats (which isn't endgame yet due to not complete) or do countless PvP for PvP gear.

If you enjoy Diablo, Torchlight, Grim Dawn, Path of Exile with MMO characteristics like World of Warcraft or Rift you will thoroughly enjoy this.  Recommended!

reviewText:
In terms of gameplay its fun to play.

But in terms of endgame..... I would STAY AWAY from this title.

Due to several changes this game is getting the same vibe as Archeage. Every new patch makes this game more pay2win and every new player has a higher wall to climb. Theyve changed ingredients from free to trade to bind on pickup, which means you can only get them from the store for money or aquire a few a day by doing daily quests.

It also has those lottery boxes like archeage, it contains most of the stuff to let you gear up quickly in the endgame, just hope you get the good rolls on it, or suffer and buy more (which is more likely).

There is also the problem of a core playerbase who got most or all endgame gear before several changes came along making it 7-10 times as hard to get. Also a few things more which im not allowed to say happened which made that starting playerbase frightingly powerful.

Because of this getting a high rank in the abyssal tower is impossible for new players.

Last but not least, because of these awkward changes and many problems not being solved at a adequate speed the population is dropping fast. So if there arent any good changes soon, this game will die a quick and silent death and became another smear on the reputation of Trion (yes im also still sore from Archeage).

TL:DR
Fun gameplay, bad pay2winfaster endgame, newcomers cant compete

reviewText:
Hi I'm F2P, cool, let's try you out.

Decent graphics, gender locked-red flag #1, but I like playing a female so no biggie to me. Got 1 toon to lvl52 (max) and one to lvl 40. Combat is fun and fast, and I would expect this from the same people who made Tera. You get 24 spaces in your inventory and trust me you're going to need a lot more, which will cost you real money.  And even if you get Patron (which is a sub) you still have to play 5 days to get 15 log in points just to buy 8 inventory spaces, red flag #2.

Making gold was very slow at the beginning but I heard it was much easier in higher levels.  Kinda true but everything costs more, you need to upgrade everything to progress in end game and that all costs in game gold.  With Patron you can buy and sell on the auction house, except there's no money to be made or never enough, which forces you to buy dex from Trion to sell in game for gold - red flag #3.

The drop rate for butchery gear (2nd highest in game) is really low unless you make pre-made parties of 3 and enter, don't look for parties you will never get a piece.  You will also need gems, runes etc.. so it's grinding the SAME dungeons over and over.

Hop on the gear treadmill 'cause it going to be a long ride, strictly for them to make more money.  Don't get me wrong, I know game makers want to make money, but this isn't the way--it's like gambling 'cause the RNG is high in this game. I spent 60 bucks and played 97 hours.  id I get my moneys worth? Kinda. Wish I would have not spent so much time on something that's going nowhere. Save your time and money. You have been warned, but it is your time and money.  Proceed with caution is all I am saying.

reviewText:
Imagine if Diablo was made in Korea.
Now, imagine if it was made into a MMO.
But, instead of using an engine designed for an ARPG, you copied over your buggy MMO engine.
Fail to consider how that engine's hit-detection will affect combat with a fixed perspective.
Next, restrict a bunch of standard MMO features behind a paywall.
Clumsily add an interesting transformation system that turns the player into a more-powerful version of their class.
Consider adding a skill tree for the transformation, but decide that would be a stupid idea.
Add a card-collection system instead.
That's this game.

reviewText:
I've played quite a fair few MMO's in my time and one's similar to Devilian, so let's get started.

Devilian has the graphics and art for a modern day, MMO, top-down RPG. The music is quite nice as well, the enemies are quite well designed - bosses especially. The NPC's repeat the same thing when you talk to them, annoying but you tune it out eventually. It's also got a nice story to go alongside it that even has a bit of side story here and there.

Character skill system is nice, you're able to reset points freely so you can try out different skills as you want to mix things up. There's 3 catergories you can choose from each with skills and bonuses towards them, as you spend more points in each one that unlocks more skills and bonuses.

There are some bugs/glitches here and there but it's early days, it's not been out long but it's pretty stable for the most part.

Contrary to popular belief, it is in no way pay to win. There is an in-game store, yes, but it only has the following: 2 mounts, some pets, cosmetic items, exp/gold boosts, inventory/character/warehouse slot increases, appearance/rename changes. Overall, nothing that constitutes as pay to win. Leveling isn't even that difficult really, it slows down as is  the case with any MMO but that's common and you can just grind out dungeons or complete the quests.

Overall, it's nice to see this type of MMO again. It's early on so give it a try and if it's not your cup of tea then leave it and come back after some updates or just don't play it. If you like Diablo, MMO's and want to try something a bit new then give it a shot.

PS: There's boob physics if you're wondering.

8/10

reviewText:
I'm writing this with about 50 hours played. I've just reached end-game content.

Game OutlineThere are 4 classes, each with a fixed gender and appearance. You can perform minor customizations, like choosing slightly different eye shapes or hairdos, but when you're zoomed out to actually play the game, there's not much visual difference between any two players of the same class.
Each class has its own skill tree. Each skill tree is broken up into 3 sub-trees, just like WoW used to have. There are no healing or tanking specs, so your choices are between 3 different DPS specs. Once people get the theorycrafting fleshed out, it's highly likely that there will be one or two cookie-cutter builds for each class.
Devilian form is a super-powered form a class. It comes with fewer abilities than your normal class. Some forms of PvP take place only in Devilian form. Outside of that, you have to kill monsters to fill a gauge. Once the gauge is sufficiently full, you can enter Devilian form for a short time.
There's the persistent world, which is broken up into instanced zones. You can switch between instances of any zone.
There are instanced dungeons. You can either solo a dungeon or go at it with a group of up to 2 other players. If you want to run a dungeon with a party but don't have any friends online, there's a dungeon finder tool that will match you with other players. While leveling, you encounter a new dungeon every level or two from level 20 all the way up to the level cap at level 52.
There's also PvP. There's world PvP events, PvP world zone instances, 3v3 arenas, 20v20 arenas, and guild vs. guild PvP. There doesn't seem to be much interest in PvP. 3v3 arenas have really long queue times. I haven't even managed to get into a 20v20 because the queue time is so long.
Now that we’ve covered the basics of what the game covers, I'll be breaking this review up into 3 parts: The Leveling Process, End-game, and Everything Else.

The Leveling Process:You gain levels by killing monsters, doing quests, or killing other players.

Like I mentioned earlier, I haven't done much PvP because there's just not that much interest in it. The classes aren't well-balanced, so anyone not playing the Evoker will have a bad time.
The quest system is about as basic as it can get. You either kill things, gather things, or interact with objects, like destroying shacks or putting out fires. There are a lot of quests, and there's virtually no differentiation between any of them. The quest text is less than engaging. I'm not even sure what the story of the game is since I skipped all the quest text after about level 3.
As with just about every other ARPG ever made, you'll spend the lionshare of your time killing monsters. Lot of monsters. You'll do it while questing and while dungeoning. Even in some forms of PvP, you'll still kill monsters along the way. Killing monsters is fulfilling. They fly all over the place when they die, like what happens in D3.
End-game:Once you've hit the level cap of 52, the game starts to narrow in focus.

There’s a D3 type Paragon leveling system which lets you spend experience past the level cap of 52 on a number of different areas. You can increase the XP you generate in certain areas of the game; you can increase the gold you gain; you can improve your DPS. Unlike D3, I like that they’ve expanded the end-game leveling system past combat stats.

For PvM content, you have the choice between doing four dungeons, one Archdevil" dungeon of greater difficulty
hoursPlayed: a tower climbing type dungeon
voteText: and world PvM.\n\nDungeons are limited to 4 different end-game dungeons and can be completed either solo or with a party of up to two other players. Each dungeon is static. Each takes less than 10 minutes to complete. There's no Diablo-type random maps. When you run one dungeon once
helpfulPercent: you've seen all there is to see of that dungeon. There is no limit to the number of regular dungeons you can do per day
votesHelpful:
which is a good thing since you'll have to grind the hell out of them to get your end-game gear.

Archdevil dungeons allow two attempts per day. Guild dungeons and the tower dungeon allow for one attempt per day. Guild dungeons allow nearly a dozen players to participate. The tower dungeon contains multiple floors. Each floor you progress to is more difficult than the last. You are limited to doing 10 floors per day.

World PvM is kind of a mixed bag. There are world bosses that need killing

The bottom line:Whether you spend real money on the game or not

reviewText:
At the time of writing the game is still newly released.

Pros:
- The fast paced mechanic is quite fun.
- Easy to jump in
- Easy to learn mechanic
- Leveling is fun

Cons:
- Story aspect is not interesting
- Too grindy at level cap (52). Grinding gems and azalea just to grind gears.
- In-game store is way too overpriced. Bought a pet, it's a permanent  but not account bound (no notification/ options for either single character or account wide), and it costs $10 approx. Not very happy with the purchase to be honest. If i had 4 characters then I had to pay $40. That's a bit too much.
- Game is not finished.

It would have been a lot better if they stated Early Access Game"

All in all not very happy. Good luck playing if you wanna have a go."

reviewText: Quick background for Individuals whom have never heard and are skeptical by the mixed" reviews it is recieveing. Devilian was originally created in Korea as a Diablo clone that was its original intention and for people saying "it looks too much like Diablo" you're correct... it's supposed to. To finally have cleared that up Devilian is an ARPG-MMO (Action Role Playing Game - Massively Multiplayer Online)

It is a fun little game until you reach the endless grind of freemium endgame.Generic story, generic UI, generic music, generic graphics, generic gameplay. It is not bad but really really bland. Feels like a tablet game or an asian grindfest mmorpg back from 2007

I can pay for stash place... it's ok, lucky boxes: well meh try your luck if you got the money, i can live with some people using xp boost, BUT whitout the Aira's blessing: http://www.deviliandb.com/item=359/airas-blessing-reward you will achieve NOTHING in the endgame, you will be just fodder. Whitout it the most needed endgame items will simply NOT DROP AT ALL, and the only way to get the buff is the cash shop, and that.. is a GAMEBREAKER for me even with the possible gold farm for the Devilian exchange item.

Game breaking exploits still not fixed that allowed many players to rise to the top and run around in  flawless gear. EDIT: This was fixed, but the xploiters received no penalty at all.

4/10 Would not even bothered to try it if some of my friends were not playing it.

reviewText:
Ignore my play time. I played off of Steam. Okay, lets get this going.
Trion is somewhat known for crushing games that showed great promise. Defiance went out with a whimper, with feint echos of crickets. Rift turned into a decent F2P to a pay to win. (And you literally have to buy certain gear slots. Earrings.)Trove has massive lag issues, and is riddled with bugs. Archeage... well.. it's Archeage. That's nuff' said.

TL;DR It sucks. Crappily designed F2P. Not worth the gigs.


I was hoping Devilian would be the redemption for Trion. Maybe they were ready to pump out a game that wasn't a huge plea of 'help we're dying' so I checked it out. The graphics are outdated, which I can handle. Little to no voice acting, and what voice acting there is, it's awful. Which I can handle. The gameplay is clunky and lazy. Some abilities simply don't work. There's no sure-fire way to level your devilian. It's all RNG. So the game feels like a cheap korean grinder as far as combat at this point.  Then we start getting into the fremium stuff. Bag slots, character slots, etc. Typical stuff. Well they released a new class; Tempest. I read the patch notes and it seemed pretty cool. So I log into the game to make one, and I only had 2 character slots. which were both reserved by a couple of characters that I've put a bit of time into. But I REALLY wanted to try the tempest and see if maybe it would be redemption points. So, I thought on it.. thought on it.. and thought on it. I came back in and deleted my least favorite of the 2 in order to create a tempest. And. Guess. What. To play Tempest, you're required to purchase the class. With. Money. Any MMORPG that forces you to BUY classes is not one worth the storage space. It's the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t F2P style ever. Cosmetics, great. Slots, cool. Mounts, sure. Storage space, why not. ♥♥♥♥ING CLASSES? No, gtfo of here with your failing dev team Trion, and don't put more of your trash out there.

reviewText:
Well lets see where to begin with this review guess ill start with the pros then end with the cons.

-Pros
-the art work is great for a f2p game and all the abilitys r nice and flashy unlike most f2p games.
-Theres tons and tons of dungeons but after reaching max lvl u go back thru them all over again on heroic/hell modes
-Each boss has different abilitys that they do plus more abilitys the harder the mode is and is kinda stratedgy based.

-Cons
-Each class is gender locked 2 males 2 females females like always are pretty much nude showing about everything to where the males look like demons and are pretty cool looking.
-It says free to play but its really not. When you get max lvl is where all the microtranactions come into play making your toons stronger altho you can get everything in game it just takes a very long time grinding it all out.
-Also on the part of it being free to play you cant talk in any chats but for guild/party if your free to play they make you pay to talk in chats meaning u either have to buy something from the market place or buy a monthly pass.
-End game is very very very grindy (5 hours of farming hell modes atm with no epic drops) since they reduced the item drop rate it made it about impossable to get epics to drop now. Tho there is 4 different modes to hell +0 +1 +2 +3, +3 being the higher drop rate but you cant get into anything +1 or higher without having atleast a few epics unless u pay gold to a stronger player to run you in +3 and hope to get a drop (which you dont always get gear for your class its mostly for other classes).
-You can only have 3 players to a party there is no real tanks or healers altho the zerker can tank and the envoker can heal it dont always work cause the envoker cant heal none stop as thier heal has a cd.
-Also you have to pay to have more inventory slots as well they only give u about 24 inventory slots for free and make you pay for the rest.

But with all that said the overall game is good to a certin degree but is very grindy at end game like a said and the way the drop rate is im figureing it will take a few days of 8 hours or more per day just to finish out your first set of epics. Tho gettin to make lvl (52 being max lvl atm) doesnt take long at all and you can be power lvled from stronger players.
But any how im done with this review and im giving it a thumbs down only cause of the huge amount of grinding it takes after reaching max lvl and seeing 0 drops after 6 hours of farming instances none stop. But if you want a game to play just to pass time then this is the game to go to even tho there is no real storyline to it the lvling to 52 was pretty fun and would do it again if they change the way the game is atm. But thanks for reading and i hope i dont a good understanding of the game.

Storyline is ok and the game mechanics work fine although the game suffers a lot or rollback issues and UI issues.

If you love Diablo3, give it a try!

reviewText:
Pretty good f2p ARPG / MMO.

The DIablo-esque combat is fun and fluid. It's grindy in a good way, and feature rich. The social aspects of the game are done particularly well, and it looks nice too.

On the down side, class and customization options are limited. There's also a cash shop, similar to other Trion titles.

All told, I'm having enough fun to recommend it.

reviewText:
Don't play it, don't play it. I'll make this as quick as I can...

Pro's:

-It's one of the few MMOarpg's out there.
-It's new, and thus will entertain you for a short while until...
-the little playerbase it has is friendly enough

Cons:

-You realise it is nothing but a casino based grind fest which has no content. (By casino based, I mean that the game revolves around chance more than anything, it tries to hook its playerbase with addiction more than fun and reward, you'll log in every day and do the dailies because you 'might' get what you want. Even the little gems you get as a daily reward to increase the stats of your heroic gear aren't 100% and instead they have a small chance to either increase a stat or a larger chance to do nothing or decrease a stat.)
- Classes are extremely poorly designed and thus
- each class is unbalanced to ♥♥♥♥ and the two ranged classes pretty much rule the game because...
- Everything about this game is anti melee, all of the bosses and everything else.
- the entire feater of this game (Devilian mode) Is pretty much worthless as you can't customize anything about it and will rarely use it because my standard form is stronger...
-The playerbase is already dwindling and has pretty much halved with the release of blade and soul, to the point the developers are giving out free gifts because they knew players would leave.
-There's no pve content, literally just 6 dungeons you do over and over and over again which rely on no tactics or anything.
-Pvp isn't worth doing because again, two classes rule it all, it's nothing but cc spamming and getting one shot.

And last but certainly not least...

- Everything about this game is systematically flawed and poorly designed. Half of the stuff in the game feels like they just threw it in there as a last minute idea. Even to the point where they LOWERED the level cap after the beta finished.

reviewText:
''FREE TO PLAY''
Until you’ve been certified as 100% human:

Your in-game megaphone will be a muted-phone, because it is disabled. Indoor voices, always!
You can only whisper with friends.
You will be able to purchase wares from the auction house, but you won’t be able to sell your own.
You can’t initiate trades in-game, but you can always agree to them.
Our postman will deliver mail to you, but won’t be able to accept your outgoing letters.
You won’t be able to request marketplace items from strangers, but you can always send pleas to your friends.

Btw - the only way to get ''certified as human'' is to buy stuff from the shop.

reviewText:
First i downloaded the game on Steam. I pressed the play button and it opened the Glyph launcher. I logged in and changed my Region to EU, because somehow it was set to US and it started to download the whole damn game again. So you end up with 2 copies of the game on your hdd. There is a way to work around that by renaming the game folder which i did. Finally i could play the game and when i wanted to start it the next day Steam gave me an error and started downloading again... So, i deleted the game on Steam, downloaded Glyph launcher and the game again. At least that worked as intended and that is why my play time on Steam is so low.

This game is free to play, but when you start you have a limited account. Limited account basically means that some basic MMO features are hidden behind a (small) paywall. With a limited account you can not whisper to strangers(only to friends), you can not sell items on the auction house, you can not initiate trades, not able to use megaphones(kind of like a global chat) and some other stuff. To verify that you are a human and the owner of the account they want you to make a purchase on any Trion game. Only then your account limitation is gone. This is a ridiculous way of forcing players to pay for their product(s) and totally anti-consumer. They limit the player experience unless you pay and in a thread on the forums someone from their team said that they want to give players the best experience possible. What a joke.

So, about 3 days ago there was a server restart. After the server came back up we lost our quest progress and items from a whole day. Big rollback. Also, people who bought stuff from the shop with real money lost their stuff. It took them a while to give us some compensation items and xp boost, but the quest progress was gone. I had to do the same quests again to get to the point where i left before the restart which was a lot. The next day they announced another server restart and said it would take 20 minutes. After 2 hours the server was still not up and if i remember correctly it took about 4 hours at the end. Then not even a day later there was a maintenance of 4 hours. Last night they announced another downtime. Almost 18 hours have passed now and the server is still not up. This is not an ARPG, this is a downtime simulator. Trion is known for server issues and it looks like they never learn. If you ever played Trove before then you know what i am talking about.

reviewText:
Alright guys i'm going to go into a pretty detailed review of what I think Devilian is worth since I have not seen anyone do a decent review yet.
I have played 200 hours in the past 2 weeks and have reached end-game content and will give you my opinion on the game.  Please enjoy.


Pros:
-There are literally no bots farming/gathering materials ever.  I have been playing and probably have seen ONE person just standing there probably with some type of mouse macro just killing useless mobs.  Mobs in the game don't give much at all, nearly nothing.  You obtain majority of the materials from dungeons.
-Combat is awesome, it's fluid with a top-down camera similar to PoE and the Diablo series
-Non-Tab targeting of course, it's an Action RPG with MMO aspects
-It's extremely easy to learn how to play
-If you want certain costumes but don't want to pay money, you can purchase in-game credits via gold legally.  There is a system called DEX" (Devilian credits) which is an item you purchase from someone for gold
date:
and when you use it it will add real world funds/credits to your account for use in the marketplace (cash shop).
-Content is actually difficult end game! Even if you have the best equipment you may not be able to clear the final boss of the Archdevil dungeons (3 man raid).  It is extremely mechanical and needs skill as the boss has certain 1 shot mechanics and multiple boss phases depending on his life total.
-3 skill trees per class so you can fine tune your build to your style.
-Skill resets are FREE.  You do not have to do anything to reset them
recommended: you just click the button and it will refund all your points for you to experiment with.\n-Dungeon party system is available and although may not be that great for early on level dungeons (nobody does them really)
hoursPlayed: it is great for finding your level cap dungeons (instant queue nearly).\n-There are 3 people per party for regular dungeons and Archdevil dungeons (which are insanely hard
voteText: mechanically & gear wise)\n-Raid dungeons will be available in the future with 9 man raids\n-Guilds are available with benefits for being in the guild (Guild dungeons
helpfulPercent: guild daily quest
votesHelpful:
rewards only obtained via guild)
-PvP available (3v3 and 20v20 battlegrounds)
-Via daily quests and log-in rewards a free to play player can be just as strong as anyone else.  (Currently near the top of the leaderboard for my class and haven't paid anything except to validate my account)
-Validating account (Could be a pro or con?).  You need to use 5 dollars in the marketplace (Cash shop) and make a purchase before your account is validated. reviewText: Devilian is a solid free-to-play ARPG that smiles like a moribund cow. It’s a summer job—you play knowing you’ll collect your fun and ultimately quit. Combat is an effervescent bloodbath broken by intermittent downtime while leveling, while the endgame is a, thankfully, endless dungeon crawl interspersed with chaotic PvP. Making it rain in-game currency will give your account VIP treatment but it’s not necessary to experience every avenue of gameplay. Had it released three years ago in North America, Devilian would have snagged players anticipating Diablo 3 and been a widespread success. In 2015 it’s a fine game, a diversion to waste time before another ARPG whisks you away.

reviewText: Let's just say that Trion succeeded in yet again, destroying a game that had promise. One of their first mistakes was to be money hungry and implement the Devilian Exchange item for in game. Anyone that had a ton of steam cash was able to purchase hundreds of these and then use the money they get from that to skyrocket to the top of the ranks. I stopped playing once their cheap servers began lagging to a point where you were unable to even get fully through a dungeon without either lagging and dying, or lagging completely out of the game and having the game crash. Oh there is also the fact that the only endgame content that they offered were farming points in certain areas called Infinite Hunting Grounds. It was somewhat manageable to compete with the other large clans because you were able to run around solo and the multiple other servers and collect points for your guild without having to run into  a massive group of 25k+ player score (over 20k is usually end game gear with decent stats). The developers then decided to make it so you could only farm and turn in points for your guild on ONE SINGLE CHANNEL! Are you kidding me? This is what fully made me quit playing this game and I do not intend on going back. Save yourselves the time and agony and skip over this game...

reviewText:
Devilian is a F2P ARPG-MMO that was made in Korea.

IN DEPTH ON GAMEPLAY:
If you have played other ARPG-MMO's such as Marvel Heroes or Path of Exile then you know what you're getting. Comparing to those alternatives the MMO is much more fleshed out than Marvel Heroes and combat is on par is Path of Exile (perhaps a bit better). There are currently only 4 classes though a 5th is on the horizon.

Action is solid and fast, enemies die with just the right attacks, they don't instantly die with basic attacks but they don't stick around too long either. Skill Trees are customizable and end-game allows for more proficiencies. Overall a very solid ARPG with MMO elements on top.

IN DEPTH ON F2P:
It is F2P, with cosmetics and xp/gold boost in the marketplace. There is an optional subscription perk called Patron that gives no real gameplay benefits, but even it can be purchased with in game gold. You must expand your inventory with store bought items like many F2P MMO's though it is cheaper than many (such as GW2) to do so. Ovreall a very fair business model.

NOTE ON LAUNCH HISTORY:
There was an issue with a EU server where many players lost a few hours of progress. It took a couple of days but Trion has since provided gear and other benefits to those affected. I'd like to point out that this happens even to games that did not just launch. I bought the Mk III pack ($100 for all heroes and storage and gems) in Marvel Heroes and after using the blender (to get more costumes) the server went down and everyone lost some game progress. I lost all the costumes and no one was compensated. Gazillian (the developer) is more well regarded by it's playerbase than Trion seems to be, as the backlash was negligable.

SUMMARY
I have enjoyed my time so far with Devilian, both as a solid ARPG game experience and with nice MMO features (guild raids, guild wars, 20v20 pvp, etc.) as a bonus. If you see the current mixed" reviews and are cautious
date: give it a try. It's free and will only cost you a bit of time if you end up not liking it."

reviewText:
The core concept of fusing aRPG with mmo-styled progression works well in theory, but Devilian fell short in its execution.

Let me first say that I have played the game extensively for the last week and with some luck and hard work gotten into end-game (partial tragedy). Many of the issues that other reviewers have mentioned (gender-locked, poor optimization, restricted trading) are apparent, but not game-breaking and can easily be brushed off with the fact that the gameplay is very satisfying. If you give the game a chance the overall leveling experience is embellished by a combat that is pleasing, fluid, and fast paced for an mmo. The game reminded me of why I enjoy top down aRPGs that give a player control of the surrounding space more than classical mmos where everything is homing and boils down to cooldown rotations. Needless to say I had fun, and didn't feel the need to pay2win beyond unlocking the marketplace.


However, at the time of this review the hardest and final dungeon (agony device) illustrates a fundamental problem with this game. I'll use it to give you a sense of what to expect from the game in the long-run.

By design you need gear from that dungeon to be able to farm that content quickly and efficiently. If you've just recently hit that progression ceiling your only options are as follows:

1. Try your best to play skillfully and slowly go through the dungeon at a snails pace.

2. Spend days of time grinding low level content to amass gold/materials to add #numbers to your vertical progression of resistances/artifacts/talismans (all de facto gold sinks).

3. Pull out the cc to accelerate the above or trade $$ for in-game gold and pay other players to carry you through the dungeon.

Point one quickly becomes moot because of the constant server issues the game has. Any prolonged gaming/dungeon session will be on a constant timer before you disconnect, lag rubber-band into death, or straight up have the client crash on you. Mind you this usually happens well over a dozen times an hour during heavy server load and is an acknowledged problem that has persisted for a while.

As for gearing up you can guess how stale and unappealing the alternatives are.
Even without turning into credit card heroes, most players at this point still opt to grind gold and have others play the content for them in the form of carry runs while they hope RNG blesses them with some drops. This seems to be a recurring theme with almost all of the end-game content, which addresses another issue: the lack of content.

For a game with so many different vertical progression components that all serve to give you the illusory sense of depth of gearing up, it's amazing how little actual content it has to offer. You will be rolling the same handful of dungeons/areas in end-game to no avail. There simply isn't anything really except for the final dungeon and daily dungeon (agony and abyssal) to challenge yourself with - both of which can only be accessed once and twice respectively a day.


So what does the game have in store for the future?
The korean servers closed months ago, so there is no future development going on in the backpipe and Trion plans to slow-roll the remaining few dungeons they have in store which will be more of the same: lots of face planting into gear-checks and endless forms of vertical progression that will funnel you more and more into what bad f2p mmos are despised for.

PvP can be fun at times, but for the most part due to lack of organization it's played half hearted by both teams and you get little satisfaction or sense of entitlement for a win. The potential for strategic depth is there, but as usual when you make pvp-rewards a means of gearing up to incentivize players you get the myriad of afkers and feeders that don't care about the outcome of the matches. Even with the upcoming pvp patches I doubt the coordination of the 20 man teams will turn it into more than another casual gear grind area.

The Diablo 3 inspired, telegraphed boss fights are fun, but in end-game they become either way too drawn out or too easy. Games like Path of Exile solved this problem by ramping up player damage output at the expense of survivability, making the experience one of dodge or die. In Devilian, especially in end-game, design directs players to address their gear whenever at an impasse granting many ways to improve damage mitigation, but only a few to improve damage. This generates the effect that players will most likely quickly transition into face tanking bosses, rather than finding ways to out-maneuver and glass cannon them. Additionally build balance seems off with crowd control driven skills being the primary means of playing the game.

For those looking for something casual to burn time on the game can offer a smile or two if you can close an eye on its flaws, but for the traditional MMO player or the challenge craving crowd I'd recommend to pass on this one.
During my one week playing the game after the initial rush from the novelty of Devilian each passing day has left a stronger bitter aftertaste as I waited for it to run its course, realizing only at the end that the game had little to offer beyond the first impressions.

reviewText:
For those thinking of joining for paying to play ... DONT... Dead game. Too late to join as a free player. Parties are extremely hard to come by. Low population.

Level fast in this game and can reach the cap in 1 to 2 days or 2 weeks for casual players.
This came as a shock to me, but was told the game really starts with the end game.

Its the end game thats disappointing which involves running the same dungeons over and over again in groups. Like in all mmorpgs, having dungeons in a game can be extremely frustrating when trying to find groups, yet this game has based nearly its whole game around finding groups. It's like they've never played a mmo/arpg before.


From there you have to repeat 15 dailies and Abyssal tower. PvP for those inclined. Guild related quests. Few of.

However the game population is dead. Only the top guilds are successful, which there are few of. Majority of players left in the game can barely complete 3 of the 15 dailies available.

New Stormfront map was questless. Which makes me suspect that future map releases will also involve questless areas.

Trion is deliberately delaying the inevitable. Shutting down the game.
Not sure how they thought they had a winning formula on their hands by thinking that running the same quests over and over again was appealing. Makes sense that the asian version of the game sunset as is the western which is still struggling to draw breath.

New Tempest class and new map area with level increase from 52 to 54 was suppose to regenerate the game... which it only slightly did for a fews days, then crashed and burned.

Not sure why Trion only lets you select 4 quests at a time. Need to let us  choose all 15 quests of our choice as groups are extremely hard to find.

Trion really let their clients down with this game.

Alot of nerfing/imbalance/repetitive grinding etc...

One thing I will say. Not a pay 2 win game

* Running the same dungeons over and over again isn't fun.... get with the programme.
* Having a 24 stand down from joining other guilds because the dang game is dead is ridiculous.  I understand a 24 hour stand down in a healthy population , not a dead one. Players need to find active guilds. Reduce the time and allow players to join guilds sooner. Really need to join a active guild if you want to complete quests.

reviewText:
This game seems to have taken a lot of flak in reviews but I really don't see what the problem is. Much of the moaning seems to be from players which have previous experiences of TRION/ Bluehole monetisation methods.
Most of the people that seem to be bashing on this game have had hundreds of hours from it which is telling really. If you've spent a load of money on this game and then regret it, more fool you.
This game has so far cost me £3.99 and that was for in-game currency. The only reason I bought this was so that I could remove the limited account restrictions applied by default. For that £3.99 I'm already approaching 100 hrs. That's much better value than 90% of the releases in my steam backlog.
I've focused so far on the PVE content which includes 3 player dungeon runs and a fair share of your kill 10 rats and go speak to this guy quests on your way to the level cap.
The game does have some issues which could do with resolving including limited UI customisation (Virtually none) and a rather annoying fps lock which seems to fluctuate around 58 fps but this shouldn't put you off.
If you enjoy ARPGs and look past the reviews I think you'll like this game.

reviewText:
I've been playing F2P Devilian non-stop since it's come out. I've ever only made one other review, but people seem to be sh*tting all over this game with less than 5 hours of gameplay invested, so I feel a more informed point of view can be of more assitance.

The game genuinely feels like Diablo and WoW mixed into one game. The first time I logged in I was greeted with a chat system where people weren't spamming like idiots. I had players running around me in the enviornment doing the same quests as I was. Yes, the mob respawn rate is very high to offput the number of players killing them. This, however, is countered by a short 'de-aggro' range, and taking damage does not knock you off of your mount, which by the way is free within the first hour of the game. I never spent more than 20 seconds waiting for a chance to activate a quest point, or wait for something to spawn so I can kill it.

There are only 4 classes in the game, but each has 3 different talent trees, which you can assign points to as you wish. I chose the Marauder class, and as such my three trees were AoE damage, Single Target Damage, or Tank-ish. It essentially turns the game into 12 classes, instead of 4.

The combat is fast paced, there are a bunch of different areas your quests take you to, each having dungeons located within them (though not the only way to get to the dungeon, as there is a dungeon finder queue), along with multiple difficulties. Ranging from Normal, Medium, and Hard. While those aren't the actual names of the difficulties, they might as well be. Medium and Hard are your end game to get gear, to my knowledge. Some of the bosses in normal dungeons were hard enough. You'll have to deal with dodging abilities, cones of damage, bombs on the floor, etc. I only imagine it gets much more difficult (and fun) at the higher difficulties.

The quests themselves aren't anything spectacular, what you'd expect. Go here, kill that, gather this, do this, that, etc. They're fast, mostly easy, and a good source of experience. I'd be a little more upset with the questing system, but it's saving grace is the auto-run feature. No, not in a straight line. Auto-run to exactly where your quest is. In fact, you can open the map, right click on a place, and you're off.

The different zones I've been to so far seem to vary in theme, some snowy, some firey, some jungle, and even desert.
You don't spent too long in each zone, maybe 2 hours depending on how fast you work through it. It's definitely a grind to get to max level, but I'm already nearly done after a few days.

So. Do I recommend this game? Yes, I do. I didn't look at the reviews as the game came out, didn't research it, just played it for what it was, and I'm having a blast.

So, let's talk about some pros and cons.

Pros:
-Easy, rewarding combat system
-Auto-run to quest locations
-Minimal fighting over mobs/objectives
-Frequent world events
-Mostly non-toxic community
-Mix and match talent system, creating tons of character options
-Quick leveling experience
-Easy to learn crafting system
-Challenging dungeons
-Full game without paying a penny

Cons:
-Limited player inventory
-Exp / Money % boosts through in-game store payed with real money
-F2P accounts cannot trade with each other (from what I hear, don't quote me on that)
-While large zones, everything feels like a tight squeeze
-Players often rewarded with megaphones" that let them broadcast 1 message per megaphone to entire server
-Definite pay to win vibe
date:
but ultimately paying will not make you stronger than a F2P account.


Don't listen to the 1 to 5 hour reviewers. Spend time in a game before you trash it.
+1"

reviewText:
This game is very unstable. Servers crash often. System is easily exploited, and it is P2W. Trion games are usually pay to win, so no surprise there. End game is really slow. Grinding is tedious and repitive. Not a lot of options after you max level cap. Bosses are predictable, no versatility or challenges.

If you are a limited account, meaning you have not purchased anything on Trion games, beware of this game. You must spend a minimum of $5 or else you will be restricted from lots of resources and vendors within the game.

I have played 431 hours so far, have 4 characters, our of 5 classes. The 5th class is only available through purchase. Again, money.

Customization is very limited. Don't expect to make your character have various tattoos or hair styles. There's about 5 you can pick from. Classes are gender locked. Only 2/5 classes are male.

Some pros for this game are: Low system requirements. Easy to master. Can be played to max level without spending money (but then you will need to spend $5 to be competitive).

Some cons other than the ones I already listed are: Guild oriented (if you don't have a good guild, you may want to unplug your computer), Tedious and time consuming grinding, Little gear options to choose from, small option pool for mounts/pets/accessories, Game is not set to Daylight Savings Time, limited released content campared to other clients in EU/ASIA, again it is a Trion related game so it will cost you some money. Open world is very small, get used  to seeing the same areas, repeatedly. PVP doesn't queue often (pigs would fly before it kicks off). Maitenance is not routinely ran on the servers or game content, so be aware bugs are frequent and they will most likely not be fixed for 3-5 weeks. This game is slowly dying (not a lot of people play this game). Camera view isn't classical third party (you have to get used to it). Not many achievements to unlock in-game and ZERO for steam.

All together, I would not play this game. I switched to Black Desert Online. This game is not recommended. Been a PC gamer for 11 years now. Some people may like this game if you're a beginner. But if you play PC MMORPGs often, this is not the game for you. Save yourself time, money, and stress and find another MMORPG.

reviewText:
This game is kind of a mixed bag for me. Pro's: it runs ok'ish (had a few crashes), looks alright and I think the music is kind of nice too (albeit repetitive, there's this piano tune you really do hear quite a lot). As you level there's factions, dungeons, daily quests, plenty to keep you busy. Not too shabby.

Cons: between mid & max level devil form is still useless and the game becomes inventory tycoon, unless you expand your inventory through the usual means. Now, if the devil form was more interesting I probably would throw some money at it because the game is kind of enjoyable. But as it stands now the game's iconic devilian / devil form or whatever is a complete bore. I feel like I'm better off not using it and I've not really seen other people use it in dungeons either. With it's iconic devil form being a letdown I feel like this game fails to stand out from the competition.

I kind of hope it's better at max level but I'm not sticking around for that. I'll go play something else.

6/10.

reviewText:
Highly recommend for fans of Diablo, Torchlight and Path of Exile.

If you've play any of the above games then you'll immrdiately pick up on this game as it plays very similar.

However the big question that everyone will want to know the answer to:

Is this game P2W?"

It USED to be P2W during Alpha and closed beta.
Trion worlds removed the dungeon Stamina system that basically limits the number of dungoens you can run per day and they also remove the stat bonuses that items in the marketplace gave you so now all clothing in the marketplace are just for vanity/transmog/glamour. :)

Mounts helps speed up travelling. That's it. Not sure if some are faster than others though.

Pets and Funtunality iterms are there for convinience.
Some pets have autoloot and some can be used as extra inventory and some can actually sell your junk so you don't have to run to the merchant everytime.

And you also have XP boost as well.

There are some questionable items in the marketplace though like you can buy an item that allows you to re-roll attributes on weapons and armour HOWEVER unlike ArchAge these stones have be gotta ingame.
Extra inventory slots can also be bought from the marketplace and also as rewards.

The Patreon perks are also gladly not P2W as it does not lock out features for non patreon players. Although some might argue that having access to a 3rd skill page is P2W but it isn't as you cannot switch while in combat. Also you can reset skill points for free as well.

For those who cannot pay fow patreon with real cash you can buy DEX from other players with ingame currency. DEX allows you to have patreon status without paying monthly.

The max level is 52 however like in diablo 3 there is another level system after you hit max level and also your devilian form can be leveled up as well.

Overall Devilian is a fun MMOARPG that you should try out. So if you are one of those "I really want to play this but it's published by Trion" give it a go. I personally feel that Trion has learnt their mistakes from ArcheAge and will not repeate the same mistake again
date: at least I hope not. Only time will tell if they start making this game P2W."

reviewText:
TL;DR: Devilian's a fun, fremium MMO in the ARPG genre. Chat and trade/auction house restrictions on limited accounts are neglegible, especially if you play to play the game in the long run (since you'll likely sub if you plan on staying around that long anyway).


To compare Devilian to Diablo or Path of Exile probably makes sense for a lot of people, but unfortunately they are not the best comparison. Instead, Drakensang Online is more appropriate as that is also an MMOARPG just like Devilian (and is technically a year older).

The reason I say this is because maps are not instances like they are in Diablo and Path of Exile. By that I mean, you don't see everyone in a town hub and they magically no longer exist once you head outside of town unless you're partied with them. No, you see and interact with other players both in towns and out in the maps - the only areas that are instanced are dungeons.

Being in the ARPG genre, you've got your mob grinding, your dungeon grinding, equipment grinding, and so on from a top-down third-person perspective. Not something that's going to entertain a lot of people for a prolongued period of time, but for those that enjoy the genre you'll be right at home.

Marketplace is currently lackluster in items outside of inventory expansion, character slots, and a small assortment of pets, mounts, and costumes. Much of everything else (XP boosts, talisman box, attribute stones, and megaphones) are gotten through the login rewards tracker as well as Archegemstones from Abyssal Tower and such. More costumes I'd expect to see added as more content from the other regions are translated and introduced, as well as things like additional classes.

reviewText:
Normally within the first hour of any MMO something grabs me and tells me I need to keep playing. Unfortunately I just didn't get that with this game. I did like the class concepts but to gender/race lock them  seems kind of limiting and with today's MMOs I don't see a real need for that. People want freedom on creating their avatar and restrictions hurt creativity. Though the big thing that made it hard for me to continue on was looking at the skill/tree system. Sure I had all these skills I could learn - I think, but the system itself is very confusing and didn't make it abundantly clear on certain aspects of learning skills and what the mechanics behind the skill was. Storage/bag space was very limited and it looks to cash shop dependent for my tastes. I can play D3 or Path of Exile at this point and get a more rewarding satisfaction of playing it and not have to worry about spending $100s just to continue playing it over a couple of months span.


Pro:
*Good Graphics
*Flashy Skills
*Auto-Pathing for Quests

Con:
*Gender/Race Locked Characters
*Skill/Tree System doesn't clarify itself well
*Doesn't feel very Free2Play friendly

reviewText:
Update: Trion Worlds has pushed an XP bonus live for affected players. 'Affected players' being people with no gear and unable to use skills. Trion claims to have sent compensation for characters who lost gear. I have received nothing. They do not yet claim to have fixed the problem with skills being disabled. Perhaps they could explain how affected players are intended to benefit from an XP bonus in an ARPG where they have no gear and no usable skills?


I registered an account on Friday using Chrome, since their website apparently dislikes Microsoft Edge. Today I logged into the game for the second time. My character had no gear at all and I get an error message when attempting to use skills. So their website didn't work properly and their game didn't work properly.

I can't properly judge their Free2Play model yet. The default two character slots feels a little stingy, but not wholly unreasonable. At the time of writing there is DLC available for €4.99, €19.99, €49.99 and €99.99. I won't be spending money on any of these until the problems are dealt with and Devilian has been stable for some time.

Overall I thought the combat was fun, the game felt responsive and it was a pleasant enough looking game. It's designed for Eastern audiences and I'm not personally fond of anime, e.g. the Canoneer class (each class is locked into a single race & gender, however there's customization options for hair style & colour, several faces, etc). The game did seem overly booby at times - rotating the Evoker results in some very noticeable jiggling.

tl;dr: Trion strikes again? The publisher doesn't have the best track record, and early problems combined with asking for €99.99 for the Immortal Pack" makes me wonder whether this is any more than a cashgrab. The ARPG / MMO hybrid has potential
date: but for now I'm sticking with Path of Exile & Diablo III."

reviewText:
Devilian offers an excellent ARPG experiance. Despite the mixed reviews i would highly reccomend this game to people who have enjoyed games like titan quest and torchlight.

Bulletpoints
- Fast paced combat where all classes feel very powerfull
- Very detailed and pretty skill animations
- Devilian form gives you a godmode transformation for the when the going gets though
- Game is paced very well and never feels like any area overstays its welcome
- Bright and colorful art style is a breath of fresh air when so many arpgs go for much darker tones (diablo and PoE)
- Very polished ui and overall game dosen't feel buggy at all
- Maps are large and well detailed

I highly recommend you give this game a go. must of the negitive reviews are from people that hate trion for whatever reason.

reviewText: This is your very typical micropurchase HEAVY MMORPG. I wouldn't recommend this in the slightest. The gameplay was shallow despite the heavy attempts at monetization at EVERY corner. This includes of course inventory (untenable without payment/questing), pets (which are useful not just stand around, VERY useful actually), potions (Of course 'devilian' form has it's own)[yes you can buy potions with ingame money but they're not as good or close later on], auction house almost locked if non pay, etc.\n\n** You actually can unlock all of these things through gold and grind of such. I still would not recommend it based on my play of it, videos I've watched and reviews of close friends.

reviewText:
This review is coming from someone who was rank 1 on the leaderboards for a while IGN - CagBag

First and formost there are a lot of debates about if this game is pay2win or not, and the simple answer is yes. Although the pay2win is not as crazy as it is in Trions other IPs it is still there. I payed approximately £50 into the game and I was top of the leaderboards for about the first week and was also the first person to own a full set Tragedy, this was mainly due to the amount of time I put into the game and days I went without sleep. But soon the people who had played a lot less and payed a lot more surpassed me on both the leaderboards and gear (which is where i decided to quit). It is true that you can play this game without spending a penny on any microtransactions you will never be able to be competative.

Okay now that that's out of the way I'll talk about some of the other Issues I have with the game and more so the Dev team. Shortly after release the Seadrift server went down for maintanence which was supposed to last for 4 hours, It lasted for almost 24 hours, and when the maintanence was finally over and players were able to log back into their server they were appaulled to find that their characters had been lost. All their hardwork, time and dedication were just completely gone. Seeing as this was a new launch we all expected their to be some issues but when this happened not once but twice in the space of 2 days that was just a joke. After people lost all their stuff they quickly rushed to get back to the end-game content and start working towards their gear all over again just to have it ripped away once more, this is totally unacceptable for a fully released game.

Gender locking. Don't do it game devs...

Although those Issues are awful they're basically the only problems I had with the game apart from the lack of quests, lore and crafting the rest I really enjoyed and felt this was the kind of game I'd been looking for.

Let's look at some of the Pro's shall we;
Fast paced action RPG style combat.
Beautiful graphics and models.
Challenging end-game content (if you're melee).
Many different distractions to take you away from the grind.
Resetable skilltree system allowing you to change the way you play constantly.
Claimable land for your guild to fight for.
Challenging guild dungeons.(unless you're in Pulse guild then it's easy :p)

As much as I enjoyed the game I honestly can't recommend this to anyone who doesn't have thausands of pounds to throw away. The main player base for ARPG's like Diablo and Path of Exile are there because of the leaderboards and striving to be the best, which is impossible unless you pay in Devillian. The same goes for MMO's with the PvP content, you want to be the best well nop surprise the PvP is the same as ArcheAge where those who pay earn the rights to use your corpse as toilet paper. However what I will say is if you have 1-2 friends who are looking to just play through the story together then you may have a good time but until you get to the end-game I'm pretty sure it's impossible to die unless you take a 5 minute break against a boss.

TLDR:
Trion Worlds.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's a little cracky like a lot of mmos, so I took it out of my steam library, but played and enjoyed it until I got to end game.  Like a lot of other reviewers said, there are substantial pay walls at end game that make it just too much of a grind.  Between enchants, salvaging, talismans, gems, artifacts, butcher runes, much less gear, it will take quite some time to grind it all out, and in-game gold (all of the previous take in-game money to advance).  If you don't get a patron account, you can't sell on the AH; if you do, you can sell some things on the AH, but not enough to really make money, unless you grind the same 4 dungeons ALL day.  I paid $40, my husband paid $60, and while we felt we got our money's worth, we started doing the grind math and it wasn't working out.   If you're looking to kill a lot of time in your life, like you're looking to drop out of college, maybe look to this, but otherwise find something better to do.

reviewText:
Just to sum up my experiences of the game so far. I believe I'll be playing this game for quite some time to come, but I'll be sure to update my review every now and then when my opinions change or differ from my initial impressions.

Purchased: Early Access Pack ($19.99)

The Good
* Fun classes
* PvP (20v20, 3v3, 6v6)
* Group finder for dungeons
* Archdevil dungeons
* Cash shop isn't P2W
(I know there are a bunch of people that claim it is P2W, but if you actually play the game and learn the systems, you will realize nothing on the cash shop is P2W, they are only slight convienances that you can buy in-game with gold or get from daily login rewards anyway)
* Abyssal Tower
* Guild system
* Autorun feature
* Proficiences (essentially paragon levels from Diablo 3)
* Salvage straight from inventory (Saves going back to town to sell)

The Bad
* Limited customization for characters
* Patron (Although I don't think rewards for being a patron are that amazing)
* Repetitive questing
* $5 to verify your account (without it, you can't talk or trade)
* Voice acting
* 58 fps lock
* Unstable servers

The Neutral
* Genderlocked classes (I personally don't mind the genderlocked classes, it's no different to Path of Exile, but I know some people mind it so I thought I'd quickly mention it)

reviewText: Its a free game for gods sake jesus christ. I mean, do you NOT want a free game? Yes you don't, unless you have a lot of memory, but still. Don't judge a game just by their reviews alone. You should at LEAST, by the very LEAST, TRY this game for yourself and feel it out. What I myself experienced, was that it's really simple to level up when you're with friends giving you the satisfaction of murdering all of mobs. Never played this alone though, so I can't really say what would happen if you go play this by yourself. I never paid attention to the storyline, usually in MMO's they feel all the same. I think this storyline is about being half devil or something like in DMC. There are 4 classes, but the classes are gender orientated giving 2 genders for 2 classes. The females are Evoker and Canonneer, while the males are Berserker and Shadowhunter. The males are usually the melee types, but the Shadowhunter could be ranged while at the same time. I still don't know much about the pros and cons but it's just something you go through. If you don't download this, then just go spend your time on another MMO that would fit your taste. There are many other MMO's on steam that you can try out, so go look for the one"."
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I feel like there's a hidden gem in this game that hasn't been found just yet. There's a lot of room for growth but my initial impressions aren't great to say the least. At first glance it looks like a cheap knockoff of Cabal - plays like it too. That's not to say that Cabal set any standards, however.

The lore is very bland. Pretty much used by every RPG ever made - some god is having a war and creatures have been created because of it so now it's our job to clean up the mess. I do appreciate a well written story in video games so this is very disappointing to me.

As far as combat goes, it feels.. off, definitely could use some work on that end. As of now it's just click and spam and the diving function is kind of unneeded it seems.

Questing is generic, pretty simple. Fetch this, kill that, spam some buttons, grab the loot. A classic ARPG element so I wont harp on that too much.. but I did expect some variety.

The UI and Graphics look fine to me. UI's are usually a deal breaker for me because I despise an interface that is difficult to interact with or one that simply looks ugly. I'd love to see the developers allow skin mods for this.

All in all I'd give this game a 4 out of 10. However I still recommend it because I think there's plenty of room for improvement and would like to see what the developers offer to this game. So give it a try, it may or may not be your cup of tea.

reviewText:
After playing this game 24/7 for the past week here is what you need to know:

Positives:
The Pvp is very enjoyable, 3/4 classes are very viable, 3v3 arena and the battlegrounds are very fun, defnietly lot of replay value.
End game PVE is fun. Challenging on occasion even.
Talent trees and classes are very enjoyable, and the biggest plus for me is you can convert gold to real money" currency that you can use to purchase items with. The items are mostly convinience/appearance so there is no "p2w" in the game.

Negatives:
Pvp arena has weak season rewards
date: but has instant rewards after winning/losing.\nRanking board does not explain lots.\nQue times for pvp are long

but thats expected of a new game with a building player base.


Overall I would definetly reccomend this game

reviewText:
I don´t see why so many people dislike this game. For me, it has everything i ever wanted to see in an MMORPG and more. What those things are you ask? Let me explain...

Let me start off with a few negative things here: The quests are extremely dull, the classes are gender-locked and Trions system to verify you as a human are a straight up obvious money grab (tho you don´t have to do it).

But what does this game have that i missed in other MMOs? Here are a few things i find in some MMOs but never united in one:

- The combat system
For me, one of the most important parts of a game, it is straight up awesome. It´s not as refined as Diablo, but it´s quick, action packed and even with my horrible interent: accurate (concerning the hitboxes). It makes fun and made me completely overlook the dulled down quest system.

- The End-Game
I hate a level cap. The only other MMO i really played was Perfect World back in the day, so i guess that´s the reason why i can´t stand being blocked in progression. I never thought this was possible, but Devilian combines nearly infinite leveling with the end-game system other games like World of Warcraft offer.
The maximum level is 52 (at the point of this review) but once you hit that, you still have to level your Devilian-Form and your proficiencies, much like the Paragon-System in Diablo 3.
And yet you get an equipment score with which you may or may not enter in some of the later dungeons. Which brings me to the next point...

- The Dungeons
Very well designed layouts combined with awesome bosses make these stand out from any other game. Throughout your journey you will enter many of them, and even at the end, they stay relevant. Farming Heroic dungeons until your gear is ready to head into Hell dungeons just so you can farm that extra bit of Resistance-Essence, Setpiece of your armor, gem to level up your artifact or other materials to improve your character makes for an endgame i´ve never seen so diverse. There is a ton of stuff to improve on which means a ton of stuff to do. Way better than just to farm for one equipment piece over and over again...

- PvP
Now i don´t mean the normal PvP, i mean real PvP. Guildwars, Arenas, PvP areas. 20v20, 6v6, 3v3. I can´t believe something like this is missing in so many games. I just love going into Teamspeak with my friends and play together against other players. It´s not as well done as in Perfect World as there is no territorial system, but it´s still a lot of fun to be had.

I could extend this list but those were the most important facts on why i think this game deserves some attention. I will keep playing it, i hope you join the party...

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this game for a while.  But I dont know what happened, I couldnt really enjoy playing the game after almost two hours.

Enemies are everywhere,  it feels croweded with them.  But none of them felt worth killing, and you have auto run options that just walk you past them.

There are fetch quests like in a MMO.. go kill 5 of these things,  fix  nets,  find some books ect.    But several parts of the quest text goes by really fast or are cut off, and other parts just feel dull and lack personality.  In the end I felt no desire to try reading them even if there was a chance of doing so.

Overall it just felt like the paceing was backwords.  The slow parts went by too fast, the fast parts felt slow, exploring wasnt very fun becaues it was too packed with enemies, and killing enemies felt unrewarding.

reviewText:
Is over 70 hours enough to give an opinion on this game? Well I have a lot of problems with this game and it's mostly just the class diversification.

Let's just say it up straight right here. If this review isn't convincing enough for you to avoid this game then please for the love of god just play the Evokers and/or Cannoneer class. There is little reason to play the other classes, whatever they may be at the time you read this review. Reason being is that right now not only are they dominating in both pve and pvp, they are the most dominant (in numbers) class in this game. Everywhere you go there will be evokers and cannoneers. Very RARELY will you see a berserker or shadowhunter... because those classes are just complete @SS.

Here's just a small example as to what I'm talking about:

http://oi64.tinypic.com/2rg2hde.jpg

That is an example of a pvp game. The pvp matchup is random but how can it be this bad? In fact this happens more often than you think. So what's wrong with that? First, level 52 is the max level in this game, but how can there be more 52s on the other side than my side. Second, the other side is FILLED with evokers and cannoneers while my side is a bit diversed, but not saying much.
To top it off with tbagging the berserker, the pvp game is almost ending, our side trailing behind by almost 1000 points; that list of players is sorted by players with the most points at the top and lowest at the bottom. Surprise surprise, the berserker on the other side is at the bottom... ANNDDDD he's level 52, the max level. Seven assists means he tried his best in battle but couldn't quite get the kill.
So what's the point of berserkers? Nothing, they are useless and so are shadowhunters.

All in all, just stick with evokers and cannonners. Why is this happening? Because every class is pretty much the same, just that ranged characters get the HUGE upper hand of dealing the SAME EXACT damage as a melee character but has more crowd control and range. If their ranged ulimate skill has the same exact cooldown and skill damage as a melee character then what is a point of a melee character? Tank? Surely nope because as you play harder dungeons, going melee is absolutely NOT RECOMMENDED because you die in one or two hits.

With that said, the devs don't know how to make a class and the berserker class shows. There are been no buffs for them and devs fail to acknowledge that this class is extremely weak right now. They will not be used in end game dungeons and they are immediately kicked when a game shows up for end game dungeons.

If you DON'T trust me then go ahead, I ain't stopping you from playing a berserker, or shadowhunter for that matter. Disregard that picture/link i posted above. Go waste your 50 hours on this class.

But honestly if you don't trust me, go play the beserker until you can queue up for pvp. Play a few rounds, like 3 or 4 and see how much ranged classes are DOMINATING. See how many cannoneers and evokers are on each side and i bet they always outnumber the other classes 3 to 1.

Don't say I didn't warn you.

Rating: 1/5. In game females characters dominate in this game. Typical for a company's only way to draw customers is to put females everywhere they can and it just so happens that the playable female characters tied to those genders are evokers and cannoneers. I mean who would want to play a sausage fest game?
